hints.content:
An $\blueE{\text{even}}$ number is a number that can be split into $2$ equal groups.

We find $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers by making sure every object in the group has a pair.

![2 rows of cookies. Row 1 has 3 cookies. Row 2 has 3 cookies. A vertical dotted line divides the cookies into 3 columns so there are 3 pairs.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9d50cd961bb1ee962eb60cc708a5e737e9d4486c)

Examples of $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers are $\blueE2, \blueE4,\blueE6, \blueE8, \blueE{10},  . .  .$

An $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number **cannot** be split into $2$ equal groups. 

We find $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers by trying to pair objects and finding there is **not** always a pair.

![2 columns of cookies. Column 1 has 3 cookies. Column 2 has 2 cookies. A horizontal dotted line divides the cookies into 3 rows so there are 2 pairs with 1 extra cookie.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/10c3af09ebfcd0c6d05b4edd219f33894cc4d8b9)

Examples of $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers are $\maroonD1, \maroonD3, \maroonD5, \maroonD7, \maroonD9, . . . $

In this image, there are $\maroonD5$ flowers.

![2 columns of flowers. Column 1 has 3 flowers. Column 2 has 2 flowers. A horizontal dotted line divides the flowers into 3 rows so there are 2 pairs with 1 extra flower.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/1f9a181b8dcdf883dd3d539a571474520a1301a5)

Each flower does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of flowers.

In this image, there are $\maroonD9$ flowers.

![2 rows of flowers. Row 1 has 4 flowers. Row 2 has 5 flowers. A vertical dotted line divides the flowers into 4 columns so there are 4 pairs with 1 extra flower.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/0d673af50eb46dae38880d2e544d80b3ba43ad06)

Each flower does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of flowers.

In this image, there are $\blueE6$ flowers.

![2 rows of flowers. Row 1 has 3 flowers. Row 2 has 3 flowers. A vertical dotted line divides the flowers into 3 columns so there are 3 pairs.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/ec0810fba4b6f1bbdce3636a88730e2ae17f8e47)

Each flower has a pair, so there are an even number of flowers.

This image shows an even number of flowers:

![2 rows of flowers. Row 1 has 3 flowers. Row 2 has 3 flowers. ](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/410d9c3ceea9080c5db8f989d698d39bab1e9cef)

question.content:
**Which image shows an even number of flowers?**

[[â˜ƒ radio 1]]

choices.content: ![2 columns of flowers. Column 1 has 3 flowers. Column 2 has 2 flowers.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/47c7af5f3b790f54f78dffa89df187a35a840730)
![2 rows of flowers. Row 1 has 4 flowers. Row 2 has 5 flowers.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/1ff322ccb063778c7141034db2b9fdcdeee60b15)
![2 rows of flowers. Row 1 has 3 flowers. Row 2 has 3 flowers.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/410d9c3ceea9080c5db8f989d698d39bab1e9cef)
